feed.title: Category: picks | User group for Viennese rubyists

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
29/01 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks – or: what we think is worth sharing – every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the fortieth edition:

Laura:
  • Austria Game Jam 2014 – The links to this year’s games are online. Play away!
  • Web applications with Ruby (not Rails) – David Padilla’s talk from ArrrrCamp.
  • Have I been pwned? – …because data breaches.
Alex:
  • 467 tests, 0 failures, 0 confidence – Katrina Owen about the purpose of tests.
  • Trailer – A faster and easier way to deal with pull requests
  • Dot Navigation Styles – Subtle effects for simple dot navigation
Ben:
  • Tales of an Ops Team: Confessions of a Chatbot
  • Prototype based programming – Featuring: Self, NewtonScript, Io, and, yes, JavaScript. Plus: the dunder is back
Tony:
  • $://showterm – Record Terminal Sessions! And it’s in Ruby, too!
  • Of Orcs and Software Craftsmanship – XML parsing, a developer’s view. Don’t let the foreign language (=Java) discourage you!
  • International Table Top Day – Play More Games! (I admit, I am a fan)

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
22/01 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks – or: what we think is worth sharing – every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the thirty-ninth edition:

Laura:
  • Nerdy Data – A search engine for source code.
  • Architecture the Lost Years – Uncle Bob’s keynote from Ruby Midwest 2011.
Alex:
  • Mocking HTML5 API – Mocking HTML5 geolocation API using PhantomJS extensions
  • Elasticsearch – ActiveModel, ActiveRecord and Ruby on Rails integrations for Elasticsearch
  • Bower and Rails – Bower and Rails on Heroku and S3
Tony:
  • How to – Convince Your Manager to Use Open Source Software
  • Valve games for Debian Developers – Open Source Pays Back
  • The world is watching via unusual channels, too – Good Luck, Ukraine!

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
15/01 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks – or: what we think is worth sharing – every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the thirty-eighth edition:

Laura:
  • The Command Line Murders – A command-line murder mystery. How cool is that?
  • Speaking.io – Thoughts on public speaking by GitHub’s Zach Holman
  • GitHub Stargazers – making your stargazers twinkle!
Alex:
  • Rails Concern – Understanding how ‘Concern’ works will help you better understand how Ruby’s ‘Module’ works.
  • Gemsurance – Gemsurance is a tool for monitoring if any of your Ruby Gems are out-of-date or vulnerable.
  • Job Stories – Designing features using job stories.
Ben:
  • RSpec Matchers – Composable Matchers in RSpec 3
  • Ruby Syntax Trivia – Neat little Ruby tricks
  • How does SSL work? – What every developer should know about SSL.
Tony:
  • try_to – Sophisticated, configurable error handling that can be used instead of Object#try.
  • “Make the world a better place” – … put a license in your gemspec.

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
08/01 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks – or: what we think is worth sharing – every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the thirty-seventh edition:

Laura:
  • Projects – A list of practical projects to be solved in any language.
  • The Mathematical Reality of Reality – An interview with cosmologist Max Tegmark.
  • Cruncher – An implementation of Bret Victor’s Scrubbing Calculator.
Alex:
  • Spacegray – A set of minimal Sublime Text 2/3 themes.
  • Sublime Ruby Debugger – Debugger plugin for interactive ruby and RoR debugging on Sublime Text.
  • CDN for Rails – Setting up a cloudfront CDN for Rails.
Ben:
  • Connection Pooling – Setting ActiveRecord’s connection pool size on Heroku with Puma or Sidekiq
  • FFmpeg Security – FFmpeg and a thousand fixes
Tony
  • Martin Fowler: Branch by Abstraction – Make a large-scale change while releasing regularily.
  • Mocks are “breaking encapsulation” – Grzegorz Gałęzowski disagrees with his notions (and I agree with him).
  • Extreme Programming, a Reflection – Uncle Bob Martin gives a lot of nostalgia a reality check. We’ve come far!

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
01/01 yesterdays picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks – or: what we think is worth sharing – every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the thirty-sixth edition:

Laura:
  • Let’s Talk About Clients – Oldie but Goldie: Michael Bierut’s talk at the NYC Creative Mornings
  • Vmail – A Vim Interface to Gmail
  • Girls haven’t been hacking for the last 10 years – A good article focusing on the heart of the problem
Alex:
  • SVG Drawing Animation – Line drawing animation with illustration fade-in
  • Haml’s little-known list_of helper – The list_of method will iterate and yield the results of the block into sequential list elements.
  • Polybox – A combo of Docker and Vagrant to make full dev environments easily available. Prestocked with boxes for Rails 4, Django, Go, Haskell, and Nodejs.
Ben:
  • Removing the GIL in Ruby – Eliminating Global Interpreter Locks in Ruby through Hardware Transactional Memory
  • Ruby 2.1 Garbe Collectors – nice write up of the changes in Ruby 2.1
  • The Lost Art of C Structure Packing
